YouTube™ Video: Random Opinion: X-Blades First Impressions 

			Views: 102		

			This is my first impressions. I didn't finish the game and i won't. Follow me on Twitter: https://twitter.com/Little_B_Gaming		

X-Blades try to be spectacle fighter like Devil May Cry, God of War and so on, but it's far, far away from them. Here you don't have different weapons to choose or set of move. You relay on two swords and guns which are useless (after upgrading the guns they start to become somewhat useful) and a lot of mashing buttons.After killing an enemy, you collect souls, which are the currency of the game, With them you can buy magic spells. You can equip four at any time. But they are almost the same!!! Lightning on sword, fire on sword, Earthquake or Fire Rage it doesn't matter. From time to time you see new skill is unlocked, you open the menu to check it and where is it? You have buy some of the available spells and then you see what is unlocked. But what if i don't want to? Well there is no choice. The spells are tight with the bosses, not all but still. For example, there is this werewolf looking boss (which i fought 3 times) For 20 min or more i didn't hurt him once, then out of frustration i open you tube. You have to buy a specific skill named Sparkling Sword to beat him. How can I know that?! There is no indication that you need it. This is the same thing for some of the other bosses. And the fights with them are too long. For activating spell you need Rage. This is why you use the swords, other than that as i wrote they are useless, so most of the time you count on spell with area of effect, like Fire Rage. Later in the game the skills are quite expensive, so prepare for grinding. The difference between area of effect spells are the animation for each one. They take you out of the action and after that the camera is in weird angle. Games like this have some sort of move to avoid attacks. Here you can buy one, but it's not that useful and a lot of attacks become hard or impossible to avoid.Graphics are good, but the cutscenes are bad, they look worse than the in-game graphics. Level design is boring, just ruins and they are basically arenas. To move to the next area you have to kill all enemies on screen.The music is okay, rock and metal tracks, probably you won't remember it. Same thing can be said about the story. You play as Ayumi, treasure hunter and she touch something and she is cursed. It's completely forgettable.I mentioned you don't have different set of moves. This isn't quite true. In the game you collect three types of artifacts. When you find enough, you gain more life or some moves for the swords or new skills for the guns (then they become somewhat useful). Let me buy them, I don't want look around just for upgrading my airstrike, which is useless!!!I can go on and on with the negativity. There is some pleasure in the mindless action, but it won't last long. I didn't expect AAA game, but me some bad design decisions ruin the potential of X-Blades. It's not the worst game i've ever played It's often on sale if you have some interest, but don't even bother.Pros: nice visuals, okay soundtrack, some mindless action, responsive controls Cons: boring level design, no debt to the combat, repetitive, some skills/spells are directly tight with the bosses and it's not at least hinted what you need to buy for them, annoying heroine, forgettable story

Posted: June 2, 2014
												In X-Blades, the player takes on the role of the enchanting heroine Ayumi, who survives a breathtaking dance of blades through the Hordes of Darkness. The long-haired beautiful anime, with her pistol blades and mind-blowing leaps, whirls and swirls from one fantastic level to the next. In brief: An anime-style, opulent hack n' slay spectacle for fans of entertaining action games. X-Blades creates a fantastic universe around the attractive heroine, who has to fend off innumerable monsters and imposing boss opponents with her power and tactics. A long list of all sorts of magic spells widens the range of potential forms of attack. Once Ayumi has collected enough experience points, she can activate new skills. The anime-style level design is what really gives X-Blades its special flair. Around 40 magical indoor and outdoor worlds dazzle in an enthralling rhapsody of color. Action and magical effects are impressively incorporated through the use of cinema stylistics such as bullet time or motion blurring.

content:
Posted: December 25, 2015
												Oh my god. Where do I even begin.A brief explanation of the plot/overview of this game, I guess (might be inaccurate since I gave up less than an hour after playing):This is a hack-and-slash game where a greedy lone wolf treasure hunter ignores the advice of an ancient temple guardian, touches a magic object (that she was directly informed by said guardian that the power within the object is completely fatal to humans; by the way, she is, in fact, a human, so she is no exclusion to this reality), and gets the♥♥♥♥♥♥cursed out of her.Alright, onto the specifics.This game tries to be fast-paced and cool with a sexy heroine main character to keep people interested (i.e. the half-dressed protagonist that has jello for breasts that will dramatically move around even if you are just walking, and whose♥♥♥♥♥is always hanging out in hopes that you stay focused on that as often as possible; I was able to ignore both things and focus on the absolute terror that was the gameplay since I have no interest in either of those subjects [laughs in aseuxal]), but in reality, this game is just a wildly unpleasant experience all around.The movement controls are disorienting as♥♥♥♥♥♥ Your default movement speed is "a desperate sprint for your life." If you jump too close to a ledge, Ayumi will abruptly roll forward instead of doing the logical thing and jumping up. The double jumping is also commonly unresponsive.The melee combat is standard at best. It controls like a hack-and-slash game. Run up to common enemies, and spam a button at everyone until they stop moving. That much is at least correct.The gun combat is honestly funny as♥♥♥♥♥♥ If you are locked onto an enemy, Ayumi will not miss a single ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ shot, even if they are all the way across the area from you. In the second level, I was practically in tears when I became a sentry gun and skipped enemies across the beach with my guns like a rock getting skipped over water. Ayumi being a sentient aimbot program is fairly useful, I guess.The magic combat is okay. In order to use magic, you need to build up "rage" by either attacking enemies until you have enough rage to use a spell, or by holding down the key/button that your spell is bound to until her rage is charged up enough to use the attack. Since this game likes to fling large hordes of enemies in your direction at once, you typically have enough rage to last you the whole fight.The combat interface as a whole is rather confusing. Nine times out of ten, I did not even know that I was getting hurt. Usually, in games with a health/damage feature, you know when you are getting attacked since your character will typically make a noise or flinch or something when harmed, or maybe the screen will flash red for a second or whatever. Ayumi does nothing if it is not a big enough attack to stagger her. I kept looking up at her health and getting surprised at how much I had lost without noticing anything.Ayumi as a character made me want to stop playing before the opening cinematic for the first level even ended. She sounds like the "mean girl in high school," and she talks as if she is above everyone else. For example, in her very first sentence, she outright states that she is "the best treasure hunter ever." That opinion is open to a staggering amount of debate, have some ♥♥♥♥ing humility. Later on, when the aforementioned temple guardian warns her that the object that she is trying to steal will straight-up kill her and tells her to leave while she still can (without trying to harm her, by the way; he was literally going to just let her turn around and walk out of the temple unharmed and without a fight), her reaction was to flip her hair, roll her eyes, adamantly state "yeah right," try to steal the object anyway while the guardian was not looking at her, and then get cursed like a dumbass since she thought that grabbing an object that is "fatal to humans" was a bright idea. For the "best treasure hunter in the world," she sure does make some ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ thoughtless decisions. I am almost completely certain that all of her previous heists up to that point were from children that were holding a coin that they found on the ground.On a related note to Ayumi, the physics in this game are abysmal. I am not talking about her earthquake jello breasts again, either. I am talking about her three ponytails. I have never seen hair move that erratically in my whole life. In every cutscene or moment of gameplay where she was moving around too fast, her ponytails went ♥♥♥♥ing ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥. They looked like the tentacles of the Kraken emerging from the waters and searching for a ship full of sailors to pull into the depths of the sea. This was a game for the Xbox 360 and PS3, too. Those consoles had pretty good graphic capabilities for their time. I am not forgiving this one. If her hair was that unstable, they should have changed it to something more usable.This game, at the time of writing this review, is on sale for $10. That is the normal retail price. But, from what I have experienced, this game certainly is not even remotely worth that much money. If you seriously want to buy the game that badly, please wait for the price to drop hard first.((I got this game for free from Bundle Stars as a Christmas "gift." I am almost completely certain that they no longer want me to be a customer of theirs.))

content:
Posted: September 27, 2015
												Think about God of War and everything that made it great aside from mashing a button to open up a chest. Now take everything and make it slightly annoying; the result is more or less X-Blades. It's a semi-fun mindless buttonmasher with minor annoyances thrown in; certain enemies are so short it's hard to hit them with your blades, bullets and spells don't always go where you want them to, the plot is just shy of nonexistant, pots are somehow immune to your swords unless you get them at just the perfect angle, certain rooms have enemies that can only be defeated in a certain way but it's up to you to guess how, certain mechanics are explained long after it would've been nice to know about them, and there's no dedicated dodge button/stick. Your rage(mana) decays unless you're in combat or getting punched in the face, so you can run into situations where you have to choice but to let some monstrosity gnaw on you for a bit while you wait to get angry enough to use the only ability that will harm it.While not good, it's not exactly bad. It's just a shame to see that it had potential yet missed the mark and dove off the cliff instead. Not really worth it at full price; I would not recommend purchasing it unless it's on sale. Also, much bloom. Wear shades.

												X-Blades... What can I say? While I can recommend this game, I would say to only buy it when on sale. It is simply not worth paying full price for. However, for under $1, you're getting a lot of game. For instance, it looks great; especially the lighting. The cutscenes and animations are relatively smooth and look nice. The voice acting is ok. The combat, while slightly repetative is satisfying and the souls system works well. X-Blades is a fun game over all, even if it is a bit mindless in some places. If you're looking for a beat em' up hack and slash style game, try this one. (Oh, and if you like thongs, you'll like Ayumi...)

content:
Posted: April 26, 2016
												This game prides itself on being Hack and Slash. It should, cause there's nothing, absolutely nothing in this game other than hacking and slashing the same generic enemies for way to long. At one point it popped up a "New Bestiary Entry", and I laughed out loud, cause 1) Where are those new enemies? They look exactly the same to me, and 2) A Bestiary? For real? This game doesn't have a plot and you gave it a Bestiary? Priorities.Also, a female protagonist with a thong? Come on man... We're better than this.The game begins with a quick 2 minutes tutorial about what weapons you have, and an elemental effect kind of damage system, which doesn't seem to matter. Jumping seems not to matter, and you can't really jump and hit aerial creatures, which seems like something you'd like to do.There was also a plot somewhere. Idk where it wen't off to.This game, however, does look pretty, requires absolutely nothing more than a simple run-of-the-mill PC to run it, and if you like the simple, non-changing, generic kind of hack and slash, you'll spend hours re-running stages here. So it has that going for it. Too bad they decided to break that beautiful scenery with awful character design and weird electronic-metal kind of music, and not something more atmospheric.For the same price tag, Darksiders/DMC/God of War early installments  are all better choices, by far, with a better setting, better plot, better gameplay.

												This game is not the best, but it is worth the 10 dollars or your regional equivilant. This game has all the things it needs to be considered a good hack and slash game: good keyboard controls,good progression, fun enemies, and some fun varying combat. Anyone that says this game is button mashy has not used spells spells are effective and fun to use, and like any good hack and slash rpg, will require careful planning on where to use them on the hard difficulty. The protagonist is a funny, overconfident, and arrogent female lead, this maybe a turn of to some but I enjoyed the humor. It is kinda annoying to see an obviously adult character act like a child, but never since Lollipop Chainsaw Massacare have we had a character like this that is so well written, so I don't really car. This game does have it's flaws though to change resolution options you have to reset the game BEFORE you can. This would be more acceptable if the game put it in the options menu and then auto saved and reset, but it doesn't. It makes you quit then start again which dosen't even matter because changing it crashes your game at random intervals. Thats right cant change resolution. Luckily the game runs well so you should have no trouble running it  on 1080. I was recording without an ssd on low graphics on 1080 on what is practiclly half potatoe, and still kept 30. If you hoped on recording this sad news, game will crash randomly at times with most software available. As well the game shows most tool tips with bot controller and keyboard mouse bindings, which dosen't cause issues, but is still really irratating. My Final verdict is that this game is indeed worth ten big ones, but may not be the best for a YouTuber or Twitch Streamer to get, however the games has a great character, fun combat, interesting skills, and a kick♥♥♥♥♥sound track. If you are a fan of Hack & Slash RPGs, and are at least OK with the anime style, this game is worth the buy.

content:
Posted: March 12, 2015
												TL;DR For a dollar with trading cards, it's an almost decent hack 'n' slash. What I feel are poor mechanics sour the experience. The devs absolutely learned from the mistakes in X-Blades and made Blades of Time a great game. Get BoT instead. EDIT: Art direction is lovely but to say succinctly what I did in a rambling way: Blades of Time is fun. X-Blades really isn't.I care not for anime sexuality.I bought this game.*GASP* How can that be?!X-Blades is the predecessor to Blades of Time; Blades of Time is a remake/reimagining of X-Blades. I got BoT in a bundle. I very much enjoyed it. I bought X-Blades in the hopes of encouraging the dev's to include Cards for BoT / Achievements for X-Blades.I did not fully grasp the significance of "reimagining." X-Blades is horrible when compared to Blades of Time. My saying so is unfair, of course, but also truth.With X-Blades, I was hoping to relive the glory days of PS2 platformers (Sly Cooper, Jak & Daxter, Ratchet & Clank, Beyond Good & Evil, KyA, Vex, etc. etc.). LOL upon further research, X-Blades was released for the subsequent generation... so my hopes were dashed from the start.Several reviews compare X-Blades to Devil May Cry; I'm pretty sure I compared BoT to DMC. X-Blades is similar to DMC only superficially: the targeting and combo system, the sword/gun-play, the double-jump, the fact that you fall slower while shooting, and of course the monsters (are vaguely similar). Other than that, X-Blades is a hodgepodge of (bad) mechanics.You're a nimble nearly nude female treasure hunting... n-nin... er s-samur... er anime. Yeah. You can swing your blades and shoot the shooty-things with the quickness; you can run (in the classic "back-bent-at-a-45-degree-angle-for-speed-and-style" pose) LIKE a ninja. When it comes to being swarmed by enemies... Ayumi moves like Zero from BoT: heavy and slow, tank-like. I'm playing with a controller and I don't even know how to dodge; I got the Teleport power, but you can only use it when your feet are planted firmly on the ground. There is no manual lock-on to enemies; moving the camera over enemies does it automatically. This makes targeting the bosses amidst the throngs of grunts a chore. The Store Page doesn't mention controller support; you can play with a controller but there are no options like Right Stick or Vibration Sensitivity (I THINK you can remap buttons but IDK). Speaking of mobs, you best get that Teleport power early on and refrain from jumping like you'd figure the agile MILF with a baby's face (yeah...) should be able to. Else, you'll float atop the mobs or, somehow, one of the grunts will end up on top of you, out of reach of your blades.Combos... I don't even know. I don't even know how the points work, actually. Your melee attacks are the only thing that multiply your combo; if you use guns or powers, you get nothing. In BoT, you could run all over the map with the (pretty much useless) points ("souls," I think) following you tirelessly - you were never going to lose any of them. In X-Blades it seems if you get too far from the points, they just disappear. If you're working on a mob, of course, the multiplier is multiplied. I think if you get hit once, you lose every bit of those banked points, rather than it just resetting to zero and getting the points you had earned. I like this idea, it is, how you say, "hardcore." When you can't maneuver well enough on your own to preserve that combo, when there isn't a block/parry; other reviews that say "The game is nothing more than spamming LMB" are correct. I hate to admit that, since that could be argued for SEVERAL games, but with X-Blades, it's absolutely true.There is a bit of a prologue and you end up being sent to some other... dimension. The beach you spawn on is apparently a hub(?). I cleared the waves upon waves of enemies, went through the door that opened, cleared the boss and those waves, didn't find another door, went back through the first, back on the beach, cleared those waves, didn't find another door, went back through the first door, and had enough. I'm certain some sorts of new mechanics / gimmicks will be employed throughout the game but I'm not sure I have the fortitude to deal with the just plain poor combat (which is, no doubt, the entirety of the game); monotony. Get Blades of Time; it is fantastic (though Ayumi is (")a bit more(") conservative).

Posted: September 27, 2015
												Think about God of War and everything that made it great aside from mashing a button to open up a chest. Now take everything and make it slightly annoying; the result is more or less X-Blades. It's a semi-fun mindless buttonmasher with minor annoyances thrown in; certain enemies are so short it's hard to hit them with your blades, bullets and spells don't always go where you want them to, the plot is just shy of nonexistant, pots are somehow immune to your swords unless you get them at just the perfect angle, certain rooms have enemies that can only be defeated in a certain way but it's up to you to guess how, certain mechanics are explained long after it would've been nice to know about them, and there's no dedicated dodge button/stick. Your rage(mana) decays unless you're in combat or getting punched in the face, so you can run into situations where you have to choice but to let some monstrosity gnaw on you for a bit while you wait to get angry enough to use the only ability that will harm it.While not good, it's not exactly bad. It's just a shame to see that it had potential yet missed the mark and dove off the cliff instead. Not really worth it at full price; I would not recommend purchasing it unless it's on sale. Also, much bloom. Wear shades.

												This game is mediocre, I would suggest it if you have nothing to play and don´t want to think too much =DIt´s not worth 10$ !Storyline is similar to "Tomb Raider" and combat system to "Devil May Cry".Gameplay => kill all enemies in "Area" / collect souls & artifacts / learn skills / proceed to next "Area" & repeat until the end.You can go back to a cleared area to grind for souls or search for artifacts you´ve missed.Pros====- lots of action & skills (blades / guns / magic)- cool heroine- nice looking cartoonish cutscenes- really good music =P- graphics are goodCons====- repetitive combat system- dull level design- annoying enemies (too small to hit / flying / immune to sth.)- not challenging
